postcontent:
I bought this Woodsmaster rifle new in 1973.  It's still in perfect condition, and I still have original box.  I've fired it less than 100 rounds over the years, probably hasn't been fired in at least 10 years.

The Remington Model 742, also known as the Woodsmaster is a semi-automatic rifle that was produced by Remington Arms from 1960 until 1980. It features a rotary breech block and side ejection port as well as a free-floating barrel.

I've also included one extra factory Magazine, and one Eagle 10-shot magazine.

The rifle includes a Redfield 4x-12x Variable Scope with parallax correction on a Redfield base and Redfield rings.  It's perfect for any size game or targets at any distance.

To keep it clean, an Outers .30 caliber Cleaning Rod.

Ammo - I can put you in the .30-06 business with a good supply of ammo and components.  I have reloaded for many .30-06 rifles over the years, and now that I'm selling my last .30-06, I have no need for the following:

8 boxes of factory ammo, one in a plastic box

Reloading Equipment:

One set of Ashurst .30-06 Reloading Dies
Lyman Precision Alignment Seating Die

Two plastiecCase-Guard carrying cases for reloads

Hundreds of empty .30-06 cases, factory and military, many cleaned and resized, ready for loading.

Eleven boxes of bullets, mostly 150 grain, by Speer, Sierra, Hornady, Norma, and Winchester.


I'm asking only $600 cash for this entire .30-06 package, the gun, scope and a lifetime supply of ammunition.  Contact me for an appointment to see everything. You will not be disappointed.

postcontent:
Up for sale is a 1980 Romanian "G" 7.62X29 AK type rifle. 
The "G" series was issued to the Romanian equivalent of the National Guard. 
Overall this rifle is in pretty good shape, with normal wear for a rifle from 1980.
Whoever put this one together paid attention to detail and did a good job. 
some serial numbers match, and from what I can tell it has a CHF chrome lined barrel. 
The furniture on it is a Balkan War battlefield take home set with trench art and notches carved on butt-stock, and a Yugo grip.  Included in the package is the original Romanian furniture set with the forward grip, one 30 round magazine, one 80 round magazine (untested), bayonet, Romanian leather 4 mag pouch and Romanian bakelite grip.  I also have 500+ rounds of 7.62 that I am selling for 23 cents per round.  This is not a top-end Arsenal, nor is it a WASR beater. I am asking $650 or best REASONABLE offer. Colt Combat Government 70 Series - 80's production.  Conservative 90% condition. Has some slight scratches in the deep Colt Royal Blue. Very slight take down mark and some evident muzzle wear from being holstered.  Comes with one 7 rd mag. Serial number 70B404xx.  Appears to be original and unmodified.  Rollmarks are light but the blue-black finish and matte slide top appear correct and original.

ADD TO PACKAGE 4/21/15
BOYT HARNESS HARDSIDE PISTOL CASE WORTH $50
ONE WILSON COMBAT 47D 8 rd MAG  WORTH $30

The Combat Govt models fell at the end of series 70 production and were a limited edition affair. The basic modifications from a stock series 70 were a silver soldered on front sight (a lot was made of that at the time) with a partridge shape like a Gold Cup or late Service Ace. The rear sight was a taller standing leaf, the same as was found on series 80's but without the dots and white outline. The top of the slide is actually not parkerized, rather it's a coarse bead blast prior to bluing. The ejection port was lowered like a commander and had the improved notch. The trigger was a long current version of the original smooth faced 1911 trigger, but was crimped onto the stirrup rather than being a one piece milling. The mainspring housing was a flat Colt commercial steel housing like the Gold Cups had with vertical serrations. The mag well was lightly chamfered on the edges The gun came in a polished blue and the slide was marked Combat Government. It will probably have a 70B prefix on the serial and have a number in the 40,000 range or so after the prefix. There weren't a large number made and the original series 70 Combat Governments are considered collectable and highly desirable today. There were a few articles written about them during the period. They were Colts answer to the idea that they should sell a gun that was essentially IPSC ready right out of the box.

Reasonable offers / trade combos considered.  My safe has 45ACP, 308, 223, 22LR and 30-30

Trade fodder?  Glock 21, 30 or 41 plus cash.

Waco/Marlin/Bryan-College Station/Centerville area

title: For Sale/Trade:  NIB Emerson Specwar
postcontent:
TOP KNIFE IN PICTURE.

From the Emerson site:

I have a 1967 Chevy Camaro.  It is fully restored with a 350 c.i. engine and it screams like a maniac when I get on it.  In my opinion it is one of the finest muscle cars ever built.  The only thing I ever did to improve it was to put power brakes on it.

Sometimes a design in its pure, raw form is as good as it ever gets.  There is no need to change it and no way to improve it.  You can tweak it, you can polish it, but that original design is the core element and that savage beauty is best expressed when it is just left alone.
There was a time when I was building knives almost exclusively for the U.S. Navy SEAL Teams.  I was spending almost as much time in Coronado as I was at home.  I was also teaching and training with the Command Master Chief who ran the entire SEAL, BUD’s training program.  As a result of that, one of the best knives that I ever designed was for them.  And it was one of my favorite designs.  It was a simple, raw, powerful design called the SPECWAR.

Like the Camaro, you could say it was a perfect expression of “Elegant Aggression.” And the knife performed.  It stood the test.  The test of men far better than myself.  And that made me very proud.

We have found 3 boxes of SPECWAR Blades that had been lost in our move a couple of years back in a recent clean up and shuffle to make room for more machinery one of the guys moving some dusty boxes said, “What are these?” And there they were.  Some of the blades were logoed, marked and even sharpened.  Some were blanks waiting to be ground.  And some of the blades were in the original Hard Chrome coating.  I think some of the dates actually go back to 2001.  So, we are now re-issuing SPECWAR knives in both Model A (Clip point) and Model B (Chisel ground Tanto).  Since we were building new handles we changed them to stand-offs and we made some color variations never before used on the original SPECWAR Models.  Of course we have the Basic Black, but in addition we have Afghan Tan, OD Green and a few Dark Woodland Green.  I forgot how good they feel in your hand until I picked one up off the assembly table. These knives are awesome.

Do not miss this one of a kind opportunity to own one of these rare, vintage, retro knives.  They are as good now, today as they were when I was putting them into the hands of the warriors who were willfully heading into harms way.  You too can own a piece of Emerson military history by picking up one of these SPECWAR re-issue knives today.  The supply is extremely limited so don’t delay.  They won’t last for long.

My Best Regards,
Ernest R. Emerson

Specs:
Overall Length: 8.63 in.
Blade Length: 3.5 in.
Blade Thickness: .125 in.

title: For Sale/Trade:  Zero Tolerance ZT0350
postcontent:
MIDDLE KNIFE IN PICTURE.

Slightly smaller. Slightly lighter. Just as aggressive than the 0300. The 0350 is 10% smaller and weighs almost three ounces less than our flagship 0300. Yet it packs a lot of features into a size that some users prefer, especially for every day carry.

Like its larger counterpart, the 0350 features the patented SpeedSafe® assisted opening system. Deploy the blade quickly and easily, even in gloves, using the ambidextrous flipper. The ZT 0350’s blade is S30V stainless steel with non-reflective black Tungsten DLC (Diamond-Like Carbon) coating. S30V steel is extremely durable, corrosion resistant, and wear resistant. In addition to providing a non-reflective surface, the black Tungsten DLC coating offers additional blade hardness and reduces friction.

This high-performance S30V blade is paired with textured black G-10 scales for a secure grip and excellent mechanical strength even under the roughest conditions. The scales are flat rather than 3D machined like those of the 0300. A locking liner secures the blade during use. The 0350 also includes ZT’s Quad-mount system for complete versatility. title: For Trade:  Gold Gold Gold
postcontent:
I have about 3 ounces of scrap gold I'm looking to trade. Most is rings and chains. All but 2 pieces is stamped with its purity. I Have acid tested all of the gold. The marks are correct. Here's a list of what I have..... 

10k gold: 1.155 grams 
12k gold: 16.700 grams 
14k gold: 85.810 grams 
16k gold: 4 grams 

Calculated down to melt value of pure gold in ounces: (weighed with a standard scale, this is not Troy ounces, just standard ounces.) 

10k gold: 0.0154. $17.94 
12k gold: 0.2683. $313.56 
14k gold: 1.6070. $1,878.11 
16k gold: 0.0858. $100.16 

Total market value: $2309.77 

For a cost of about $100 it can be smelted down to a bar of pure 24k gold in the weight of about 1.9756 ounce. Market value of it is about $2300 depending on when you do the calculations. 

With gold value always changing I'm setting my trade value at $1600. If I get a chance to take my gold to the smelter before trading it off the price will change. I just wanted to try listing it before I smelt and sell it outright. I can acid test it in front of you to show purity

No I will not just sell the gold as is. My plan is to try to trade it or next week I'm going to smelt it and have it poured into a solid 2 ounce bar. 

Now for what I'm looking for. I'm really looking for guns, AR's, bolt actions, lever actions, pistols. I will also trade for ammo, reloading supplies, gun safes, hunting equipment. As for specifics..... I'm looking for a 458 socom, 50 beuwolf, 338 federal, 454 casull revolvers, single action 357's, Winchester model 70's, Remington 700's, 1911's, 338 lapua, long range 308 or 300 win mag. I'm sure there's a lot more so email me any trade offers.

title: For Sale:  Mueller 3-9x40 EER Scope
postcontent:
I have for sale a used Mueller 3-9x40 Extended Eye Relief scope - pretty decent scope for the money. Nitrogen filled, multi-coated optics, standard duplex-style reticle. It is surprisingly bright & clear for a scope in this price range...I have read reviews that say otherwise but from my experience it compares well to the older Leupold VX II's that cost considerably more.
No lies, this scope has been used but not abused - definite ring marks but the glass is perfect. The scope held zero without any problems when I tested it on a 300 Winmag. It was actually used on a muzzleloader at typical U.P. December temps/low light conditions and did just fine there.

I'm in no hurry to sell this one - but I'm raising money for this year's hunting adventures, and this scope is an extra. $65 plus shipping makes it yours. Comes with the original box.

title: For Sale:  Arsenal SAM7UF Milled Underfolder AK
postcontent:
I have a like new SAM7UF Milled Underfolder in 7.62.39mm. Exactly 300 rounds fired. Complete with sling, oil bottle, cleaning kit, manual, 10 round magazine. The underfolder locks up very tight with zero play. Awesome rifle. Muzzle nut and a classic slant muzzle brake. Power Custom pin retaining plate installed. I am firm on the price. The underfolder also has a braided 550 cord for comfortable cheek weld. 



-Rifle
-Sling, oil botle, cleaning kit, manual
-10 round mag
-Slant brake
-Muzzle nut
-Power Custom retainer plate
-30 round steel mag
-original and bakelite pistol grips


594 in full effect


The SAM7UF
Arsenal, Inc., the premier American importer and manufacturer of semi-auto rifles, is proud to offer to American shooters the new addition to the SAM7 family – the SAM7UF rifle. This 7.62x39 caliber rifle combines authentic, high-quality features expected in the SAM7 Family. From its reinforced under-folding buttstock to its 14x1mm left hand muzzle threads with muzzle nut, every component of the SAM7UF is engineered to provide decades of dependable and accurate service. The SAM7UF rifle is bound to become a sought-after and collectible firearm.

The New Reinforced Under-Folding Stock
The SAM7UF utilizes the modern straight-back under-folding stock, which locks perpendicular to the action and the bore of the rifle. In order to provide a more secure and firm lock, whether in a folded or extended position, this stock locks on both sides of the receiver with 4 solid pins. The reinforced, straight-back folding stock stabilizes the rifle which significantly reduces the climb and gives the shooter much firmer control over the firearm for improved accuracy and effectiveness. These are major improvements over its predecessor, the tilt-down stock, and this rifle will surely exceed it.

Arsenal’s Exclusive Milled And Forged Receiver
Each SAM7UF receiver is milled from a hot-die hammer forged receiver blank by the Arsenal Co. of Bulgaria. Other milled-receiver AKs are machined from bar stock, but Arsenal’s hot-die hammer forging produces stronger and finer-grained steel. Internal voids and cooling deformations are eliminated by the 5-ton hammer forging process.

Each forged receiver blank requires over 5.5 hours of milling before assembly. This forging and milling process is complex and time-intensive, but Arsenal’s meticulous attention to detail delivers a receiver of unequalled strength, precision, and durability.

SAM7UF-85 | SAM7UF model 7.62x39mm caliber rifle, milled and forged receiver, chrome lined hammer forged barrel, 14x1mm muzzle left-hand threads, muzzle nut, bayonet / accessory lug, reinforced under-folding buttstock, black polymer pistol grip and handguards, stainless steel heat shield, cleaning rod, one 10-round magazine (accepts any mil. spec. magazine), sling, oil bottle, and cleaning kit.

FEATURES
100% new-production parts and components
Bulgarian hot-die hammer forged receiver, bolt, bolt carrier, and double-hook trigger
Cold hammer-forged 16.3” barrel from Arsenal’s Bulgarian factory, built on Steyr manufacturing technology
Hard-chrome plated bore and chamber

Removable muzzle nut with 14x1mm left hand threads
Reinforced Under-Folding Buttstock
922(r) compliant with US made or imported magazines
Substantially extended service life over other types of assemblies
Accepts any standard mil-spec high capacity magazine

postcontent:
Do-All Outdoors .38 to .44 Auto Reset Targets were specifically designed to give shooters of .38 to .44 caliber handguns and rifles a handy, self-resetting target system for convenient, hassle free shooting. This set of targets consists of three 4.5" targets arranged along a horizontal bar. The two outer targets on this Do-All Outdoors product spin and lock in the upright position when hit and return to the initial lowered position when you hit the center reset target, completely eliminating the need for a time-wasting manual reset. Safety and stability are also features of the Do-All Auto Reset for .38 and .44; the Do-All Outdoors targets' forward lean deflects stray bullets into the ground, while the stabilizing ground spikes keep the unit firmly anchored to the turf. Blast away to your heart's content without ever taking time out for a reset with the Do All Outdoors Auto Reset .38 to .44 Targets.

title: For Sale:  Winchester SX2 Practical Competiton Shotgun
postcontent:
Offered for sale is a Winchester SX2 Practical shotgun.  This is a semi-auto gun designed for 3 gun competition but very useful as a "house gun" as well. It was considered one of the fastest semi-auto shotguns ever made.  This is NOT the regular SX2 which is a wood stock, "duck gun".  This is a light weight, high speed pellet throwing machine!

Winchester ceased production several years ago and sold the rights to the gun to FNH, which produces the same gun today as the SLP (Self Loading Police).

It features an 8 round tube plus one in the chamber and can be "downloaded" in 2 seconds or less!

Check these two links:

http://www.winchesterguns.com/products/catalog/historic-detail.asp?family=009C&mid=511015
http://www.fnhusa.com/l/products/le-products/shotguns/slp-series/slp-mki/

I have no need for the gun, but I also don't "need" to sell it, so reasonable offers considered.  The original price for this gun was close to $1300!

postcontent:
The PVGC smallbore silhouette rimfire match is designed for all shooter skill levels, and features NRA hunter pistol targets engaged at four separate distances in three shooting positions. This match will teach shooters: firearm safety, proper range etiquette, and basic marksmanship skills. The course of fire will be challenging enough to promote growth, and enable graduation into other match disciplines. This squaded individual match is ideal for any pellet and rimfire rifle or pistol, typically in .22 LR. Shooters may compete in the class that best suits their equipment, and enter up to two guns when permitted.
Matches take place in Reno, Nevada. Please check our [URL="http://palominogunclub.org/33/pvgc-event-schedule/"]event schedule[/URL] for match/practice dates, or read or [URL="http://palominogunclub.org/262/smallbore-silhouette-rimfire-match-description/"]match description[/URL] for full event details. title: For Sale:  1893 Winchester 12ga.
postcontent:
I have a Winchester 1893 that I would like to sell.  It is the precursor to the 1897 and fairly rare.  I believe the 1893 was the first commercially produced pump shotgun, and it was John Browning's first slide action patent.  Aprox 34,050 were made during the period where the industry was switching to smokeless powder.  The 1893 had a reported mechanical weakness when used with smokeless powder which was reinforced with the 1897.  So Winchester offered anyone with an 1893 to return it and exchange it for a shotgun of their choice.  (possibly being the first American firearm recall) So it is hard to say how many 1893s are still in circulation.  Winchester may have data.  

This is a great piece for a collector.  The 1893 has a lot of history, and this one is a pretty decent survivor.  You can see by the pictures that it is not in 100% condition.  It was not locked in a vault.  It was used, taken care of, and aged gracefully.  I would like $600 for it.  

If you have any questions please feel free to ask.    

Located in Trinidad, Co

title: For Sale:  7.62x51 -- 112 grain milsurp ammo ($.50/rd)
postcontent: FOR SALE: 300 rounds of 7.62x51 ammunition. These are Spanish 7.62x51 CETME rounds. Instead of the regular NATO weight of 147 grains, these are 112 grains. That means a lot less recoil, and much more fun shooting. The ammo is packaged in twenty-five 20-round boxes; each box is stamped with the date of manufacture. The entire lot appears to have been made in December 1962. The ammo is brass and super clean (see photos). These came from the famous Santa Barbara ammunition plant in Toledo, Spain. This plant is still producing ammo for Spain's armed forces. Note that the primers are corrosive (common feature of European munitions) so give your rifle a nice cleaning when you're done shooting and you'll be fine.
